physDesc.p: The letter consists of three pages with typewriting on both sides. The corners of the pages are rounded as if they came from a journal and one side is torn, indicating it was torn out of a book. The bottom of each page has two holes punched out. In several places there are pencil writings indicating new words to add or crossing out words to subtract. On the top of each new sheet (every other page) there is a page number in the middle of the page.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: Your two letters are here, and I am very glad you are going to get Fletcher’s and my long poem into “The Egoist,” for I am sure they are better than the short ones. You do not tell me whether you like mine or not, but I live in hopes.

Things are maching[sic] splendidly here. I enclose the first criticism which, as you perceive, is rotten. Not uncomplimentary, far from it, but ununderstanding. Some people think the man who wrote it an excellent critic. He is a regular Transcript poetical critic, and was so interested in the coming out of this number that he begged advance sheets; and as there were none, I had to give him my proofs. It is amusing to see how little he understood our preface, how incapable he is of comprehending what we are driving at. Greenslet says he thinks that most people will be impressed by the space given us, however, so that is something to the good anyway. This is our first advertisement. Of course, we shall use reviews when we get some. I think they have done rather well on this, although of course our aim is not to connect poetry with life exactly. But that is advertising ways, and one cannot kick.

The advance sale of the book, before it was out, was 481 copies, and Greenslet seems quite pleased with us. He told me to tell you to get your six other copies at Constables, because he does not think there ought to be too many with the American title-page floating round. He thinks Constable will get after him, if there are.

The bookshops I have arranged to carry the May number of “The Egoist” are the Old Corner Bookstore in Boston and Lawrence[sic] Gomme’s Bookshop in New York. The Old Corner is one of the oldest and the best patronized in the town. Gomme’s is new, young, energetic and up-to-date. They are thinking of publishing some broadsides à la Monro later, and it is a very good place indeed for us to have the paper.

Miss Weaver writes me that the Studio Bookshop here has asked for five numbers, and she writes to ask me if that is the bookshop I have been speaking about; but it is not. The Studio Bookshop is a little, one-horse concern, up a flight of stairs in a narrow strict, with a stock of something like ten books, and I cannot imagine what sort of a clientele. It is run by a man named Brown, whose chief drawback to for the place is his complete ignorance and his lack of artistic standards. I was only in there once, and I tried to get a copy of “The Poetry Review” which so gloriously slammed me. Brown himself was out, but his father and the office boy kept offering me every other conceivable review and asking me if that was the one. Even the files of the magazines they took were not up to date, so I am afraid much can not be expected from them.

Greenslet tells me that you have written to ask him if he could not get something from for Lawrence and your little Belgian chap. I do not understand about Lawrence, for I got Greenslet to any that he would like to see his last book, the short stories, with a view to publishing it here, as long ago as last November, I think. I wrote Lawrence asking him to send Greenslet a copy of either the book or the manuscript, and nothing ever arrived.

I am awfully glad that Greenslet succeeded in getting de Gourmont’s articles into The Transcript. I never thought of The Transcript as a possible place for them; and anyway, I have not the pull that Ferris has, of course, as his firm has a large advertising contract with The Transcript. I think Ferris is behaving extremely white with us. He has been awfully sick with me because he wanted to publish my French lectures that are coming out in the Autumn, and Macmillan got in first. But in spite of that, and I do not know why he was so anxious for them, for I can hardly suppose they would will sell to any vast extent, he goes right on being especially nice to us all.

Fletcher seems to have settled down here for the present. He has lodgings in town, and he is working very hard. He has written a splendid poem called “Clipper Ships,” one of the best things he has done, I think.

If you should care to come to America, I have a little job for you, which you could begin with and which might lead to others. I know I could get it for you. It is translating French songs for a music publishing house here. One of the men in the firm is an intimate friend of mine, and he has tells me that it is extremely difficult to get good translators. Of course, you know translating to music in a very different thing from translating without it. I have done considerable for him at one time and another, but I am so busy now with my own work that I have had to refuse to do any more of that. But as they are hunting all the time for translators, should you ever feel inclined to come over here, I think you could make enough money at that, if you learned to do it with the technical skill required by which of course I mean musical accents and such, to keep you very comfortably while you were pushing in to the reviews. Of course, I have no authority whatever to say all this, only this friend of mine was telling me his difficulties the other day. He is a composer and I am translating some songs of his for friendship’s sake; but I told him I could not do any more, because I have to re-write my entire volume of French lectures for the press and translate about 125 poems quoted in them for the appendix–that the publishers insist upon.

I am awfully sorry you do not find the interest you are looking for for the new review. It is just as bad over here, and in some ways worse for of course printing is so much higher. Harold Monro sent me his new book. I think some of the things in it are not so bad as I expected; but what struck me particularly was the way it was issued and the low price at which it sells, when you think that Ferris could not make our volume pay at less than seventy-five cents.

I am awfully amused at Ezra’s Anthology, and his asking Monro to contribute. It shows he has had a hard time to find anybody to take our places and act as cluster-stones about his center-piece. Will you send me a copy of his “Cathay?” I should like to see it. I have no idea of the price of it, so I am enclosing a money-order for five shillings to pay for it. If it is more, I will send the balance. If it is less, send me Hueffer’s “Antwerp” with the rest. In fact, I guess I will make the five shillings ten, and let you send me the “Antwerp” anyway, and also Ralph Hodgson’s “Eve,” which is nicely rhymed, as I remember, and any other of Monro’s recent chap books which you think worth my looking at.
I gave a talk at the Round Table Club here about ten days ago on “The New Manner in Modern Poetry,” and I read your “Poplar” and Hilda’s “Sea Iris” with great effect.

I am sorry you do not like Fletcher’s article on me. He read the first draft to me, and it seemed to me too unqualified praise, as I told him, but I confess I am too unused to praise not to be pleased that he wanted to write it and felt that way.
I have written to “The New Republic” to send me back your last volume of essay on de Gourmont; but so far I have had no answer.

By the way, what do you want me to do about your book. You told me that a Boston publisher was nibbling at it, but you never told me his name. Am I to send it to you or send it to him, because I do not like to have the responsibility of it, I am so afraid something will happen to it.

I do hope you and Hilda will like the anthology we have worked so hard to get. I think myself it is an extremely good book now that it is out. I will send you all the clippings as they come in, good, bad, and indifferent, and I wish you would do the same by me, in England. I subscribe to a clipping agency there, but I do not think they send me half the things that come out from what I hear from Mr. Macmillan. I have been gloriously slammed in the English papers, that is one sure thing. Now I suppose they will have a fine time rapping the Anthology.
Mrs. Russell is in Chicago with her daughter or she would join me in sending lots of love to you and Hilda.

div.note: Perhaps a typo for “marching,” or suggests early use of contemporary verb maching, meaning to move along swiftly, derived from the name of Austrian physicist Ernest Mach (1838-1916) who theorized shock waves. Mach numbers, a unit of measure used to describe quantum force beyond the speed of sound, were named for him in 1929, postdating this letter and Lowell’s life, but she most likely would have been aware of him and his scientific philosophies.
Lowell identifies this reviewer for the Boston Evening Transcript in a later letter to Aldington as William Stanley Braithwaite, literary editor of the paper from 1906-1931. See AL to RA May 6, 1915.

The Old Corner Bookstore, on the corner of School and Washington Streets in downtown Boston was built in 1718; it operated as a bookstore from 1828-1950; Laurence J. Gomme took ownership of The Little Bookshop Around the Corner in New York City in 1912, from Mitchell Kennerly, who had founded it in 1907. Gomme published imprints with his business partner, Donald Vaughn, from 1913-1914 and from 1914-1915 under his own imprint.

Edmund R. Brown’s Studio Book Shop, located at 68 Pemberton Sq in Boston published the annual Poetry Journal under its imprint from 1912-1918. Brown served as an assistant, associate, and managing editor during its run.

Belgian painter and writer Jean de Bosschère (1878-1953), who translated articles by Aldington for Mercure de France and whose articles on the destruction of Belgium during the war Aldington suggests Lowell find an American publisher for in his April 5, 1915 letter.
D.H. Lawrence, The Prussian Officer and Other Stories, London: Duckworth, 1914.
Most likely composer Carl Engel, who worked as an editor for the Boston Music Company from his arrival in Boston in 1909 to 1922.
Harold Monro, Trees, London: Poetry Bookshop, 1915.
